{{Infobox sports season | title = 2009-10 Pac-10 Women's Basketball Season |caption=#193980 | color =#193980 |color text =#FFFFFF | league =[[NCAA]] Division I | sport =[[College basketball|Basketball]] | logo = | pixels = | caption = | duration = | no_of_teams = 10 | attendance = | TV = | draft = | draft_link = | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular Season | season_champs = Stanford | season_champ_name= Champion | league_champs = | league_champ_name= Runners-Up | second_place = [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]] | MVP = Nneka Ogwumike | MVP_link = 2009â10 Pacific-10 Conference women's basketball season#Awards and honors | top_scorer = | top_scorer_link = | promote = | promoted_from = | relegate = | relegate_to = | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | conf1 = | conf1_link = | conf1_champ = | conf1-runner-up = | conf2 = | conf2_link = | conf2_champ = | conf2-runner-up = | playoffs_MVP = | playoffs_MVP_link= | finals = Tournament | finals_link = 2010 Pacific-10 Conference Women's Basketball Tournament | finals_champ = Stanford | finals_runner-up = [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]] | finals_MVP = Nneka Ogwumike | finals_MVP_link = Most Valuable Player | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = Basketball | prevseason_link = | prevseason_year =[[2008-09 Pacific-10 Conference women's basketball season|08â09]] | nextseason_link = | nextseason_year =[[2010â11 Pacific-10 Conference women's basketball season|10â11]] }} {{2009–10 Pacific-10 Conference women's basketball standings}} The '''2009â10 Pacific-10 Conference women's basketball season''' began in October and ended with the Pac-10 Tournament on March 11-14, 2010 at the [[Galen Center]], [[Los Angeles, California]].<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/championships/pac10-championships.html 2009-10 Pacific-10 Conference Championship Sites/Dates], ''pac-10.org''</ref> [[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]] won both the regular season and the tournament championships. Stanford and UCLA were selected to participate in the [[2009â10 NCAA Division I women's basketball season|NCAA Tournament]]. Stanford was the runner-up of the [[2009â10 NCAA Division I women's basketball season|NCAA National Championship]] and completed the season with a 36-2 record.<ref>Associated Press,[http://www.ncaa.org/wps/portal/ncaahome?WCM_GLOBAL_CONTEXT=/wps/wcm/connect/ncaa/ncaa/ncaa+news/ncaa+news+online/2010/division+i/connecticut+rallies+to+keep+streak+alive_04_07_10_ncaa_news&utm_source=delivra&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=NCAA%20News%20Direct Connecticut rallies to keep streak alive], ''NCAA News'', April 7, 2010</ref> Cal won the [[2010 Women's National Invitation Tournament|WNIT Championship]].
==Pre-season== * [[Michael Cooper]] was hired as new coach for the [[2009â10 USC Trojans women's basketball team|USC Trojans]]. * [[Paul Westhead]] became the new coach for the [[2009â10 Oregon Ducks women's basketball team|Oregon Ducks]].
2009-10 Pac-10 Women's Basketball Coaches' Pre-season Poll: * 1. Stanford *2. California * 3. Arizona State * 4. UCLA * 5. USC * 6. Washington State * 7. Oregon State * 8. Oregon * 9. Arizona * 10. Washington
==Rankings==
* Stanford has been ranked #2 in the polls. * March 1, 2010 â [[UCLA Bruins]] is rated No. 25 in the [[ESPN]]/[[USA Today]] [[Coaches' Poll]]. * March 8, 2010 â Stanford #2, UCLA #23 (AP Top 25). * April 7, 2010 â Stanford #2, UCLA #23 (final USA Today/ESPN coaches poll)
==Conference games== * January 31, 2010 â At the half point mark of the conference season, Stanford is on top of the standings, followed by UCLA and USC at second place.
==Conference tournament==
{{main|2010 Pacific-10 Conference Women's Basketball Tournament}}
2010 [[State Farm]] Pacific-10 Conference Women's Basketball Tournament was a post season tournament for the women's basketball teams in the Pacific 10 conference. The games were held on Thursday through Sunday, March 11-14, at the [[Galen Center]] (Los Angeles, California).<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/w-baskbl-tourney/ Tournament 2010 State Farm Pacific-10 Women's Basketball Tournament], ''Pac-10.org''</ref> Tournament winner became the [[2010 NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] automatic qualifier. Stanford again was the winner.
Last year, Stanford won the tournament over USC, 89â64.
==Head coaches== {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} * Niya Butts, Arizona * Charli Turner Thorne, Arizona State * Joanne Boyle, California * [[Paul Westhead]], Oregon * LaVonda Wagner, Oregon State {{col-2-of-2}} * [[Tara VanDerveer]], Stanford * [[Nikki Caldwell]], UCLA * [[Michael Cooper]], USC * Tia Jackson, Washington * [[June Daugherty]], Washington State {{col-end}}
==Post season== ===[[2010 NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]=== * Saturday, March 20 - First Round, #1-seed '''[[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]]''' def. #16-seed UC Riverside 79â47, at Sacramento Regional, [[Stanford, CA]] * Sunday, March 21 â First Round, #8-seed '''[[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]]''' def. #9-seed NC State 74-54, at Kansas City Regional, [[Minneapolis, MN]] * Monday, March 22 â Second Round, '''[[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]]''' def. #8 [[Iowa Hawkeyes|Iowa]] 96-67, at Sacramento Regional, [[Stanford, CA]] * Tuesday, March 23 â Second Round, [[2009â10 Nebraska Cornhuskers women's basketball team|Nebraska]] def. [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]] 83-70, at Kansas City Regional, [[Minneapolis, MN]] * Saturday, March 27 â Second Round, '''[[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]]''' def. #5 [[2009â10 Georgia Lady Bulldogs basketball team|Georgia]] 73â36, at Sacramento Regional, [[Sacramento, CA]] * Monday, March 29, '''[[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]]''' def. Xavier 55-53, at Sacramento Regional Finals, [[Sacramento, CA]] * Sunday, April 4, '''[[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]]''' def. Oklahoma 73-66, at the Semifinals, [[San Antonio, Texas]] * Tuesday, April 6, 5:30 PM, Connecticut def. Stanford 53-47, [[Alamodome]], [[San Antonio, Texas]] ([[2010 NCAA Women's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Championship Game]])
===[[2010 Women's National Invitation Tournament|WNIT Tournament]]=== * Wednesday, March 17 â '''California''' def. UC Davis 74-69 (OT), 7 p.m. PT (First Round) * Wednesday, March 17 â '''Arizona State''' def. New Mexico State 84-61, 6:30 p.m. PT (First Round) * Thursday, March 18 â '''Oregon''' def. Eastern Washington 95-66, 7 p.m. PT (First Round) * Tuesday, March 23 â BYU 61, Arizona State 53, 9:30 p.m. ET (Second Round) * Tuesday, March 23 â '''California''' 64, Utah 54, 10 p.m. ET (Second Round) * Tuesday, March 23 â '''Oregon''' 93, New Mexico 67, 10 p.m. ET (Second Round) * Thursday, March 25 â '''California''' 71, Oregon 57, Eugene, Oregon (Regional) * Saturday, March 27 â '''California''' 76, BYU, 50, Haas Pavilion, Berkeley, California (Quarterfinals) * Thursday, April 1 â '''California''' def. Illinois State 61-45, Normal, Illinois (WNIT Semifinals) * Saturday, April 3 - '''California''' def. [[Miami Hurricanes|Miami]] 73-61, Berkeley, California (WNIT Championship Game)
===[[Women's Basketball Invitational|WBI Tournament]]=== * Wednesday, March 17 â '''Washington''' def. Portland 75-44 (First Round) * Sunday, Mar. 21 â Texas A&M-Corpus Christi def. Washington, 59-58 (West Region Semifinals)
==Highlights and notes== * January 21, 2010 â Pacific-10 Conference issued a public reprimand to Michael Cooper for his post-game comments following USC's game with UCLA on Sunday, January 17.<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/012110aab.html USC Women's Basketball Coach Reprimanded], ''pac-10.org'', January 21, 2010</ref> ==Awards and honors== ===Scholar-Athlete of the Year=== * [[Jayne Appel]], Stanford â [[Toyo Tires]] Pac-10 Women's Basketball Scholar-Athlete of the Year ===Player-of-the-Week=== 2009-10 Pac-10 Players of the Week:<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/020110aaa.html Pac-10 Women's Basketball Player of the Week], ''pac-10.org''</ref> {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} * Nov. 16 â [[Nnemkadi Ogwumike]], Stanford * Nov. 23 â Nicole Canepa, Oregon * Nov. 30 â Kayla Pedersen, Stanford * Dec. 7 â Amanda Johnson, Oregon * Dec. 14 â Nnemkadi Ogwumike, Stanford * Dec. 21 â Kayla Pedersen, Stanford * Dec. 28 â Sami Whitcomb, Washington * Jan. 4 â Taylor Lilley, Oregon * Jan. 11 â Nnemkadi Ogwumike, Stanford {{col-2-of-2}} * Jan. 18 â Davellyn Whyte, Arizona * Jan. 25 â Alexis Gray-Lawson, California * Feb. 1 â Markel Walker, UCLA * Feb. 8 â April Cook, Washington State * Feb. 15 â Jayne Appel, Stanford * Feb. 22 â Jayne Appel, Stanford * Mar. 1 - Jasmine Dixon, UCLA * Mar. 7 â Ashley Corral, USC {{col-end}}
===All-Americans===
===All Pac-10 teams=== The awards listed below were determined by vote of the conference coaches and announced on March 11.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.pac-10.org/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/031110aab.html |title=Pac-10 Announces 2009-10 Individual Women's Basketball Honors |publisher=Pacific-10 Conference |date=2010-03-11 |accessdate=2010â03-11}}</ref> *Player of the Year: [[Nnemkadi Ogwumike]], [[2009â10 Stanford Cardinal women's basketball team|Stanford]] *Freshman of the Year: Davellyn White, [[2009â10 Arizona Wildcats women's basketball team|Arizona]] *Defensive Player of the Year: Briana Gilbreath, [[2009â10 USC Trojans women's basketball team|USC]] and Rosalyn Gold-Onwude, Stanford *Coach of the Year: [[Nikki Caldwell]], [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]]

===USBWA All-District team===
===Women's Basketball Media Awards=== These end-of-season honors were voted on by media and announced on March 9.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.pac-10.org/sports/w-baskbl/spec-rel/030910aae.html |title=Pac-10 Announces Women's Basketball Media Awards |publisher=Pacific-10 Conference |date=2010-03-09 |accessdate=2010â03-11}}</ref> *Player of the Year: Nnemkadi Ogwumike, Stanford *Freshman of the Year: Davellyn White, Arizona *Defensive Player of the Year: Ify Ibekwe, Arizona *Coach of the Year: Nikki Caldwell, UCLA
'''2010 Pac-10 Media All-Pac-10''' * Nnemkadi Ogwumike, Stanford * Jayne Appel, Stanford * Alexis Gray-Lawson, California * Kayla Pedersen, Stanford * Ify Ibekwe, Arizona * Jasmine Dixon, UCLA * Ashley Corral, USC * Taylor Lilley, Oregon * Danielle Orsillo, Arizona State * Davellyn Whyte, Arizona * Jeanette Pohlen, Stanford * Markel Walker, UCLA * Talisa Rhea, Oregon State * Sami Whitcomb, Washington * Briana Gilbreath, USC
